paper_overview.citation: Vaid, M., Sarma, K., Kala, P., & Gupta, A. (2022). The plight of Najafgarh drain in NCT of Delhi, India: assessment of the sources, statistical water quality evaluation, and fate of water pollutants. Environmental Science and Pollution Research, 29, 90580–90600.
paper_overview.study_region: Najafgarh drain and its tributary secondary drains in NCT Delhi, India, including confluence with Yamuna River at Wazirabad

data_sources.description: Status of wastewater treatment plants (STPs and CETPs) in Najafgarh drain basin
Description of secondary drains with locations, discharge volumes, and land use characteristics
Comparison of Najafgarh drain water quality at entry point (N1/Dhansa) and exit point (N15/Wazirabad) for 25 parameters across both seasons
Range of physicochemical and microbiological water quality parameters in secondary drains (N=8) for both seasons
Pearson correlation analysis of water quality parameters
Pearson correlation analysis of heavy metals
Graphical representation of water quality changes at upstream/downstream locations for each secondary drain and Yamuna River
Heavy metal concentration ranges (referenced but not shown in main text)

extraction_notes: 1) Table 3 contains full data for sites N1 and N15 only (entry and exit points of Najafgarh drain). 2) Table 4 contains min/max ranges for secondary drains (S1-S8) with site identifiers in parentheses. 3) Figures 3-10 contain graphical data for intermediate Najafgarh drain sites (N2-N14) and Yamuna River sites (Y1-Y2) - these would need to be extracted from bar charts. 4) Coordinates are provided only for secondary drain sites (S1-S8) in Table 2; Najafgarh drain sites (N1-N15) and Yamuna River sites (Y1-Y2) lack coordinates. 5) DO was reported as 'ND' (not detected) for all secondary drain sites and some Najafgarh drain sites. 6) Lead (Pb) was mostly 'ND' across sites. 7) Heavy metal concentration ranges are stated to be in supplementary Tables S1 and S2 which are not included in the main document. 8) The paper uses 3-day BOD at 27°C (Indian standard) rather than the more common 5-day BOD at 20°C.
